title: Technical Issue Affected Capital One Accountholders
summary: Some bank customers had problems accessing their money. Some Capital One Financial Corp. customers were having problems accessing their money on Friday.

title: White House Expected to Ban Vape Flavors Except Tobacco and Menthol
summary: Under the plan, mint-which represents about 70% of Juul's U.S. sales-would be taken off the market. The Trump administration is expected to announce next week a decision to take off the market all e-cigarettes except those that taste like tobacco and menthol, according to a White House official, revising its previous plan after pushback from conservative groups who argued it could hurt the president's standing with voters next year.

title: Barneys Flagship Store to Remain Open, But Not as Barneys
summary: The retailer's new owner, Authentic Brands Group, will turn the space into pop-up shops after a liquidation sale. Barneys New York Inc. began liquidation sales Friday at all of its stores, including the company's flagship Manhattan location, which will remain open but without the Barneys name.

title: Brazil Police Suspect Greek-Flagged Ship Was Source of Oil Spills
summary: Vessel that docked in Venezuela in July may have been source of slicks staining hundreds of beaches. SÃO PAULO-Brazilian investigators have identified a Greek-flagged ship as the main suspect behind oil slicks that have stained hundreds of beaches in Brazil's northeast since late August, potentially solving the mystery of what caused the country's biggest-ever oil spill.

title: Google to Buy Fitbit, Amping Up Wearables Race
summary: Deal to acquire maker of wearable fitness products for $2.1 billion extends Google's reach in consumer electronics. Google reached a deal to buy wearable fitness products company Fitbit Inc. for roughly $2.1 billion, a move that intensifies the battle among technology giants to capture consumers through devices other than smartphones.

title: Katie Hill Tries the Al Franken Defense
summary: If she's a victim, then why not stay in Congress and fight?. Freshman Democratic Rep. Katie Hill is resigning from Congress after news (and nude photos) became public that revealed a relationship with her now ex-husband and a 22-year-old female subordinate on her payroll. We'd normally leave this story to our friends at the New York Post and Politico, but then the 32-year-old Ms. Hill decided to invoke what we think of as the Al Franken defense.

title: More Good News for Workers
summary: The resilient labor market continues to exceed expectations.. Politicians deal in exaggeration and deception, but sometimes you have to wonder if they even read the words that someone puts out in their name. Witness House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's statement Friday on the surprisingly good monthly employment jobs report: "The October jobs report offers further evidence that the Republicans' disastrous special interest agenda is hollowing out the middle class while enriching the wealthy and well-connected."

title: America's Miracle Medicines
summary: The biotech cures keep coming, if politicians don't get in the way.. Another week, another U.S. medical breakthrough. The latest in the annals of American innovation is a new cystic-fibrosis gene therapy that will help patients with the debilitating disease live comfortably for decades longer. Remember this the next time politicians, on the left or right, complain about greedy drug companies.

title: The Last Man of Letters
summary: 'I don't see a decline,' the 94-year-old critic John Simon says. 'Looking back into the past always makes it look better than it actually was.'. New York

title: The Wrong Impeachers
summary: A large swath of Trump-skeptical voters haven't forgotten the Democrats' Russia collusion hoax.. Donald Trump keeps it simple, and likely too simple given Ukraine's opaque and corrupt politics, when he says Joe Biden arranged the firing of a Ukrainian prosecutor looking into a company that employed his son.

title: Kentucky Governor's Race Tests Trump's Re-Election Strategy
summary: Matt Bevin is abrasive and unpopular. Can he win a second term on a campaign of provocation?. Few observers view crimson-red Kentucky as a political bellwether. But next week's gubernatorial election, pitting Republican Gov. Matt Bevin against Democratic Attorney General Andy Beshear, may answer a question on many minds: Can an unpopular GOP incumbent with a penchant for provocation win re-election amid a divided electorate?

title: Like Trump, Justin Trudeau 'Lost the Popular Vote'
summary: Canada, Israel and other democracies prove that 'political reform' schemes create their own problems.. What are elections for? The most common answer is to discern "the will of the people," and ideas for making America's electoral system more responsive to majorities are gaining momentum.

title: Notable & Quotable: Little Free Libraries
summary: 'The only real impact of LFLs is liberally performative self-gentrification.'. From a flier posted on a Little Free Library in Washington's Mount Pleasant neighborhood:

title: Trump Floats Iowa as Venue for Signing U.S.-China Trade Pact
summary: Two countries had hoped to sign deal on sidelines of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation in Chile, but the summit was canceled due to violent protests. WASHINGTON-President Trump suggested Friday that Iowa could be the venue to sign a "phase one" trade agreement between the U.S. and China.

title: Oil Rises on Strong Jobs Report
summary: Crude prices posted their largest one-day gain since mid-September. Oil prices rose on Friday after a strong October jobs report helped reassure investors about the pace of U.S. economic growth.

title: Facebook, Restaurant Brands, PG&E: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Facebook Inc.

title: Trump Will Tap Texas Doctor to Lead FDA
summary: White House plans to name an acting chief of the agency pending confirmation process. WASHINGTON-President Trump intends to nominate oncologist and hospital executive Stephen M. Hahn to be the new commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, the White House said Friday.

title: High Court Weighs SEC Clawbacks
summary: Power to require wrongdoers to disgorge billions of dollars in ill-gotten gains is under attack. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court said it would consider a challenge to a key enforcement tool of the Securities and Exchange Commission: the ability to claw back ill-gotten gains from those who commit financial fraud.

title: Firefighters Battle New Blazes in Southern California
summary: The National Weather Service extends warnings of powerful winds and low humidity that can make fires more dangerous into Saturday afternoon. Firefighters across California are finishing a week spent battling at least one major fire a day, as powerful winds and low humidity continue to plague much of the state.

title: Collins Fundraises With Rival of Maine Shipbuilder
summary: GOP senator launches ads in effort to save her seat; Elizabeth Warren wades into Philadelphia council races. SUSAN COLLINS LAUNCHES EFFORT TO SAVE HER SEAT, and potentially the Senate Majority, from Democrats. The Maine Republican debuted two new advertisements this week, touting her bipartisan credentials and pushing back on attacks from "extreme left groups." One ad credits her for bringing "thousands of good-paying jobs to Bath Iron Works," a major shipyard owned by General Dynamics that produces military vessels.

title: Trump Administration Stops Enforcing Some Nondiscrimination Provisions in Federal Grants
summary: HHS proposes rule allowing grants to flow to private, faith-based groups that refuse to work with gay or transgender people. WASHINGTON-The Department of Health and Human Services will no longer require organizations that get billions of dollars in federal grants to comply with rules that ban discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and religion, the agency said Friday.

title: Warren's Medicare for All Would Leave Mark on U.S. Economy
summary: Detailed plan on health, taxes might crimp investment while lowering out-of-pocket costs. Sen. Elizabeth Warren's new Medicare for All plan would leave a sizable imprint on the U.S. economy, altering consumer spending and business investment while upending the health-care sector.

title: California Governor Threatens State Takeover of PG&E
summary: Gavin Newsom says state may intervene if shareholders, bondholders cannot quickly reach a deal to exit bankruptcy. California Gov. Gavin Newsom is threatening a state takeover of PG&E Corp. unless the company exits bankruptcy and dramatically improves the safety of its electric grid before the next wildfire season.

title: U.S. Government Bond Yields Climb After Jobs Report Exceeds Expectations
summary: The 10-year Treasury yield rose to 1.72% from 1.67% before Friday's jobs report. U.S. government bond yields rose Friday after data showed the economy added more jobs than expected last month, a sign of ongoing growth.

title: U.S. Launches National Security Review of Video App TikTok
summary: Move follows concerns from U.S. senators that Chinese-owned company censors content to appease Beijing. The U.S. has undertaken a national security review of the popular video-sharing app TikTok, following concerns expressed by U.S. senators that the Chinese-owned company was censoring content to appease Beijing, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: S&P 500, Nasdaq Close at New Highs
summary: Stocks climbed Friday on a stronger-than-expected jobs report. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite closed at new highs Friday after a strong October jobs report reassured investors about the pace of growth.

title: New Ford-UAW Contract Reflects Gains Won After Strike at GM
summary: Ford workers will get pay increases, maintain low health-care costs, but Ford will close engine plant in Michigan. The United Auto Workers' new labor deal with Ford Motor Co . largely mirrors the contract agreement struck with General Motors Co . last month after a 40-day strike, but with some exceptions.

title: New York Fed Adds $104.583 Billion to Markets
summary: The injections are aimed at ensuring that the financial system has enough liquidity and that short-term borrowing rates remain well-behaved. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $104.583 billion in temporary liquidity to financial markets Friday, when it also added permanent reserves to expand its balance sheet.

title: Trump Administration Delays Rule Forcing Hospital-Cost Transparency
summary: Officials want to compel insurers to disclose negotiated prices as well.

title: New York Fed's Williams Says Economy Is Strong
summary: John Williams also offers upbeat take on jobs growth. NEWARK, N.J.-Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams said Friday the current setting of short-term rates was at the place that should keep the economy moving forward in the way central bankers wanted to see.

title: Terrorist Attacks Increase in Africa's Sahel, U.S. Warns
summary: State Department points to risk of fleeing fighters finding a new haven in semiarid belt south of the Sahara. WASHINGTON-Africa's Sahel region is emerging as a new frontier in the fight against terrorist groups, according to a new State Department report, following a doubling of attacks recorded last year.

title: Proxy Advisory Firm Sues SEC Over New Rules
summary: Institutional Shareholder Services says guidelines that require firms to explain advice are an abuse of the agency's power. The nation's biggest shareholder advisory firm sued the Securities and Exchange Commission over new guidelines meant to give investors more transparency into how proxy advisers make their recommendations on director elections and other corporate-governance ballots.

title: Grant and Lee's Beards Never Saw Gas Masks
summary: Beards interfere with the wearing of oxygen masks in aircraft, firefighting breathing apparatus on ships and with the wearing of chemical and biological protective masks.. I laughed when I read M.L. Cavanaugh's "The Military Shouldn't Shave Its Numbers" (op-ed, Oct. 29) about how to jump-start military recruiting by allowing beards. I realized Mr. Cavanaugh's real-world disconnection from how the U.S. military operates when he wrote: "The worst-kept secret in the U.S. military is that special-operations units routinely choose to go razor-free and everyone simply looks the other way."

title: Alzheimer's Is Multiply Cruel and Isolating
summary: Until we address this need in the treatment of a growing population of needy citizens, we will continue to see isolation, despair and exhaustion among sufferers and their caregivers.. I just visited my dear friend who has dementia and resides in a memory-care facility. The article "The Isolation Alzheimer's Brings" (Life & Arts, Oct. 28) prompted me to visit her even though we usually run out of conversation quickly. I took an album of photos of a trip we had taken together 30 years ago in Japan. We chatted and laughed over the pictures, and it was a heartwarming visit. She became quite animated and could recall many little things about Japan. Thank you for reminding me of my friend and the importance of spending an hour reminiscing together.

title: California's Hostile Constitutional Takeover
summary: The last time Democrats were so enthused about states' rights was in 1860 when South Carolina seceded from the Union.. Your editorial "California vs. the Constitution" (Oct. 29) indicates that the Golden State began testing constitutional boundaries that inhibit its progressive course when Congress failed to act on climate-change policy. California's 2013 cap-and-trade agreement with Canada's Quebec province is finally being challenged in court by the U.S. Justice Department for violating a constitutional provision that prohibits state deals with foreign powers unless Congress consents.

title: Most Farm Subsidies Go to Nutrition for the Poor
summary: About 80% of the farm bill goes for "nutrition" (i.e., welfare) spending for urbanites.. Not included in the Oct. 24 letter from Sara Stevenson, sharply critical of farmers because of federal farm programs, is any recognition of the reality of the farm bill-that as much as 80% of it goes for "nutrition" (i.e., welfare) spending for urbanites, and more than half of the remainder goes for crop insurance and price-deficiency subsidies so that farmers won't quit because farm-gate commodity prices don't equal the actual cost of production.

title: The Impeachment Needle and Bipartisan Unsavoriness
summary: If the president's inquisitors had just a smidgen of curiosity about the Biden clan's clearly unsavory activities it might be a little (but not much) easier to take them seriously.. Regarding Peggy Noonan's "The Impeachment Needle May Soon Move" (Declarations, Oct. 19): Perhaps the needle may move, but to most observers the impeachment fuss is on the same dreary continuum as Trump the Russian asset, Trump the racist, Trump the sexist, Trump the ogre-attempts to undo the last election without giving the voters a chance to weigh in. If the president's inquisitors had just a smidgen of curiosity about the Biden clan's clearly unsavory activities it might be a little (but not much) easier to take them seriously.

title: Jorge Masvidal Knocked a Guy Out in the Time It Took to Read This
summary: The veteran UFC welterweight has the fight of his life against Nate Diaz on Saturday in New York City. There's a big, rowdy UFC mixed martial arts fight at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, and it isn't for a particular weight-class championship, but something called the "BMF" title. I would tell you what the "BMF" stands for, but this is The Wall Street Journal, people, and I would get canned. I don't want to get canned. I can tell you the B stands for "Baddest," and the M stands for, well, "Mother." I'll let you figure out the rest. I guess I could condemn the UFC for being foul-mouthed, but they're already fighting in a cage, folks. It's never going to be Wimbledon.

title: Mergers Become a Possible Lifeline for Under-Pressure Car Industry
summary: Trade wars, tech upstarts, slumping markets have all combined to drive auto consolidation. The proposed merger of Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot applies an old auto-industry recipe to new challenges: Use size to boost profit amid changing consumer habits and the most-expensive technology transition in years.

title: In Private and Public, Trump Leads Impeachment Response
summary: President focuses in a variety of settings on the House inquiry into his Ukraine dealings, as his advisers work to craft a clear message. WASHINGTON-President Trump's vociferous rebuttal of the House impeachment inquiry, featured most prominently on his Twitter feed and at campaign rallies, is spilling into unrelated private meetings inside the White House, as his aides try to develop a more structured and consistent response to the probe.

title: Recreational Runners Stand to Benefit the Most From the Nike Vaporfly
summary: Elite marathoners have been smashing records while wearing the superlight shoe. Nike says that it can improve a runner's time by up to 4.2%.. The most controversial shoe in sports, the Nike Vaporfly, has become increasingly ubiquitous on the feet of elite athletes during several record-setting marathons in the four years since its debut. Now, data suggest its lure is trickling down fast to everyday marathoners, who may actually stand to gain more from wearing the shoes.

title: Top Fed Officials Signal Comfort With Pause in Rate Cuts
summary: Richard Clarida, Randal Quarles both said the monetary-policy stance was 'likely to remain appropriate' as long as supported by data. Top Federal Reserve officials underscored the central bank's expectation that it could pause from further rate cuts as it assesses the economy in the coming weeks during remarks on Friday.

title: Nigel Farage's Brexit Party Fires Election Warning at Boris Johnson
summary: Launch of campaign comes after Trump said a trade agreement would be difficult under prime minister's Brexit deal. LONDON-Nigel Farage, leader of the upstart Brexit Party, described British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's divorce deal with the European Union as a "sellout" and threatened to run a national election campaign against him unless he promises to ditch the agreement.

title: RBG Deserves to Be Believed
summary: A new tale from Bill Clinton implies that she misled the Senate.. Remarks by former President Bill Clinton this week appear to contradict a 1993 sworn statement from Ruth Bader Ginsburg about their discussions prior to her confirmation as a Supreme Court Justice. History suggests readers should be skeptical of the Clinton claim.

title: Warren Would Tax the Wealthy and Companies to Pay for Medicare for All
summary: Democratic presidential candidate had been pressed to explain how she would fund health plan. DES MOINES, Iowa-Sen. Elizabeth Warren said that as president she would tap billionaires and large employers to pay the bulk of $20.5 trillion in new spending over a decade to finance her Medicare for All health-care plan, promising to shield most Americans from higher taxes under the proposal.

title: A Warming One-Pot Chicken Stew
summary: In this simple recipe from chef Kwame Onwuachi, chicken thighs braise in a rich, spicy sauce. IT'S TIME TO break out your braising pot. Fall's here, and the late-season vegetables, spices and aromatics in this particular braise-onions, peppers, tomato, ginger, garlic and curry powder-will wrap your kitchen in a cozy fog as they simmer away on the stove.

title: Job Gains Help Extend U.S. Economic Growth
summary: U.S. payrolls grew by 128,000 in October. WASHINGTON-The U.S. economy has cooled but continues to expand with employers hiring, consumers spending and growth stabilizing.

title: North Korea's Strong Hand Against the U.S.
summary: With his nuclear arsenal firmly established, Kim Jong Un is in no hurry to make a deal, and he knows that President Trump is unlikely to seek confrontation. For Halloween, Kim Jong Un gave Donald Trump a trick, not a treat: North Korea fired two short-range missiles on Thursday toward the Sea of Japan. It was North Korea's 13th weapons test this year-and the first since the Trump administration's latest attempt to restart negotiations with North Korea quietly failed a few weeks ago. The first talks between the two sides in eight months broke down after only 8½ hours in Stockholm. The North Korean delegates stalked out, and Pyongyang subsequently said they wouldn't resume the "sickening" negotiations with the U.S.

title: Twitter's Facebook Trick Is Bittersweet
summary: Twitter says it will ban political ads, but Facebook plans to keep profiting off them. The great October debate over political ads on social media has thrown up both tricks and treats for investors.

title: Photos: Flames Fueled by Strong Winds Rage in California
summary: Wildfires have prompted the evacuation of tens of thousands of people. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Artist Andy Goldsworthy Tries to Capture a Sense of Time
summary: One of his boldest projects yet, 'Walking Wall,' has been meandering across 5 acres in Kansas City. When it rains, Andy Goldsworthy likes to lie on the pavement and then rise to see a fleetingly dry echo of his body. Making art is his way of understanding the subtle shifts and changes taking place around him. At the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., where the British artist has been working on a big site-specific installation, he has spent several mornings standing still for around 90 minutes at sunrise to watch his shadow move across a chimney, which he noticed glows at dawn.

title: Positive Signals in AIG's Noisy Quarter
summary: A big miss on earnings per share shouldn't obscure solid improvement in the insurer's core business.. Some key indicators at American International Group Inc. are pointing in the right direction.

title: Logistics Hiring Growth Slows on Industrial Weakness
summary: Truckers expand payrolls but warehouse hiring is tepid heading into holiday season. Truckers edged back into hiring mode last month as overall logistics-sector job growth remained muted ahead of the holiday peak.

title: Fitbit Is Google's Latest Stretch
summary: Deal could be risky given how big tech companies are under intense government scrutiny for their scale and influence. Google's deal to buy Fitbit is riskier than it looks.

title: Nintendo's New Fitness Toy: Burn Calories While Battling Monsters
summary: Can the Ring-Con, a hybrid gaming/workout toy, really help adults stay in shape? We sweatily found out. OVER THE YEARS videogames have made me smile and laugh and yell and even contemplate my existence. But until today they've never made me sore. My muscles are aching (just a little) after spending a morning sparring with monsters and dragons while wielding Nintendo's latest exercise device, the Ring-Con.

title: Taking Instruments to New Heights
summary: On its eponymous debut album, the Allman Brothers Band put time-tested ingredients together in a new way and used maverick instrumentation to create a fresh, funky sound.. The Allman Brothers Band's eponymous debut album, released Nov. 4, 1969, rose to the level of classic art, pushing the boundaries of electric guitar, rock and improvisatory American music to establish the Allman Brothers as one of the foremost rock bands in history.

title: California Fire Danger Continues to Worsen, Experts Say
summary: Construction near wildlands, climate change and lack of burning are major contributors. As California is living through the most dangerous time of the year for wildfires due to dry and windy conditions, experts say a trio of factors make America's most populous state more at-risk than ever.

title: Stocks Get Through October Unscathed
summary: Though October threatened with a reputation for market havoc, investors actually found an opening. In the end, there was no big October surprise for the U.S. stock market.

title: For GM, the Strike Was Worth It for the Long Run
summary: The real stakes weren't wages or benefits, but the auto maker's right to run the company as it sees fit. The United Auto Workers spent the 1980s primarily worried about job security. As Japanese car companies stole Detroit's market share and robots invaded auto plants, union bosses anticipated less for their army of workers to do.

title: California Fires and Blackouts in Photos: What We Know
summary: Resume Subscription. Wind-driven wildfires and mandatory blackouts have become a new normal for Californians.

title: What Parents Need to Know Before Borrowing Money to Pay for College
summary: A Direct Plus loan? Home equity? Parents should understand the pros and cons of all their loan options.. With college costs burgeoning, parents often consider taking on debt to help their children cover tuition. It could be a smart move. But it could also have a devastating financial impact, so parents should understand the pros and cons of each option.

title: 'Bellwether': The Head of a Herd and Now a Leading Indicator
summary: A term for what lies ahead started out as a ram leading sheep around. Savvy financial prognosticators know to be on the lookout for the performance of "bellwethers"-those companies and industries that serve as leading indicators for the rest of the economy. One traditional bellwether, U.S. manufacturing firms, may not actually be so predictive anymore, as a recent Wall Street Journal headline announced: "U.S. Factory Slump Shows Manufacturing Isn't the Bellwether It Used to Be."

title: Vietnam Told China to Get Out of Its Waters. Beijing's Response: No, You Get Out.
summary: South China Sea was site of monthslong standoff with a Chinese oil-and-gas survey ship; Beijing accused of trying to impose its rules over region. HANOI-For months earlier this year, Vietnamese officials tracking the operations of a Chinese oil-and-gas survey ship off their country's coast in the South China Sea sent urgent communications to Beijing, demanding that the vessel leave Vietnam's 200-nautical-mile exclusive economic zone.

title: Booze, Breakfast, Sword Fighting-At a Dubai Brunch, Entertainment Is Included
summary: Resume Subscription. DUBAI-Ramon Salto walked through his restaurant at the five-star Le Meridien hotel on a recent Friday to check on preparations for the $145 brunch: oysters on ice, bottles of Veuve Clicquot Champagne cooling in a bathtub.

title: Former NYC Marathon Leader Talks Doping, Shoes and World Records
summary: Mary Wittenberg says pro cycling's history should teach running's leaders to be vigilant about cheating, and calls on Nike to use its influence for reform. Mary Wittenberg was president and CEO of New York Road Runners and race director of the New York City Marathon in 2005-2015. Now president of the EF Education First Pro Cycling team, she spoke with The Wall Street Journal about recent marathon world records, the influence of Nike and the shoe technology that might have aided those records, and the four-year suspension for doping conduct of Nike Oregon Project head coach Alberto Salazar, who won New York in 1980, '81 and '82. Answers have been edited for brevity and clarity.

title: Trump to Host Washington Nationals at White House
summary: President to honor first World Series-winning team from the nation's capital since 1924. WASHINGTON-President Trump will host the Washington Nationals on Monday, the White House said, following the first World Series win by the hometown team in nearly a century.

title: A White Woman Searches for Her Black Family
summary: Resume Subscription. Christine Jacobsen grew up thinking of herself as white. She was raised by white parents. One day, she took home a DNA test.

title: Thumbs Up for Jobs Growth, Thumbs Down for Efficiency
summary: Despite everything, companies keep hiring. That might be because it is the only way to keep up.. Companies are in a funk, and yet they keep hiring. They may not have much choice.

title: Investors to Big Oil: Make It Rain
summary: Shareholders skeptical of fossil-fuel companies want more cash, but the pressure is straining balance sheets. Investors want just one thing from the world's biggest oil companies: cold, hard cash. But it is becoming harder for the oil giants to deliver.

title: Found: The Best Affordable Black Ankle Boots for Women
summary: When did that indispensable staple-the simple black bootie-become a luxury item costing four figures? Our correspondent hunts for better value. A RECENT SEARCH for durable-yet-chic black ankle boots at department stores revealed a shocking fact: Boots have stealthily become very expensive. Mortgage-payment expensive. A buttery leather pair with a shiny gold zipper from Gianvito Rossi retails for $1,195. A glance around the shoe department reveals that its equally gorgeous mates from Chloé, Gucci, Christian Louboutin and Tom Ford all cost much the same. Flip them over, see the price, gasp, and slam them back on the gleaming white shelf. It's like a game of Whac-A-Mole, but for middle-aged women like me who remember, back in the Dark Ages of 2009, when the priciest shoes rarely topped $700.

title: Global Factory Slowdown Takes Toll on Jobs
summary: Surveys of purchasing managers show factory output continuing to weaken in many parts of the world. Factory output continued to weaken in many parts of the world during October, according to surveys of purchasing managers, though there were signs of mild improvement in the U.S.

title: China Tightens Online Sales of E-Cigarettes
summary: Regulators issue notice ordering e-commerce platforms to shut sites in a bid to curb underage vaping. BEIJING-China called on companies and e-commerce platforms to stop selling e-cigarettes online, in a bid to curb underage vaping as global health authorities raise alarms about its potential effect on public health.

title: China Pushes to Integrate Hong Kong Through Patriotic Education, Security Overhauls
summary: Beijing adopts directives intended to strengthen ties with the city, including retooling its political and economic system. China plans to ramp up efforts to integrate Hong Kong with the mainland by strengthening patriotic education and retooling the city's political and economic system, amid continuing protests against Beijing's growing influence in the former British colony.

title: An Oceanfront Summer Cottage in Rhode Island
summary: Designed by Giancarlo Valle, the home has sold for $17.6 million. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: An American Duchess Takes to the Barricades
summary: Meghan Markle's activism may alienate the British public from the monarchy.. Once again, it seems, there's some kind of deep-state American plot under way to destroy the British monarchy.

title: Deal for Rhode Island Mansion Is the Second-Largest Closed in the State
summary: The property, sold by hotelier Kevin Wendle, is just two houses away from a mansion owned by the pop star Taylor Swift. On the coast of Rhode Island, a New England shingle-style mansion just two doors down from the oft-photographed home of pop star Taylor Swift has sold for $17.6 million.

title: New Nets Owner Joe Tsai's Views on China Bring U.S. Backlash
summary: Angering some Americans, the co-founder of Alibaba says he represents the Chinese view. BEIJING-After Joe Tsai bought the Brooklyn Nets in September, his focus was on unseating the Knicks as New York's favorite team. Instead, the billionaire co-founder of Alibaba quickly found himself embroiled in the National Basketball Association's showdown with China.

title: The Rising Threat of Digital Nationalism
summary: As the internet turns 50, the global vision that animated it is under attack. What can be done?. Fifty years ago this week, at 10:30 on a warm night at the University of California, Los Angeles, the first email was sent. It was a decidedly local affair. A man sat in front of a teleprinter connected to an early precursor of the internet known as Arpanet and transmitted the message "login" to a colleague in Palo Alto. The system crashed; all that arrived at the Stanford Research Institute, some 350 miles away, was a truncated "lo."

title: Sometimes the Stock Market Needs 'Knights of Faith'
summary: It's a lot easier than it used to be to recover your losses after the market takes a tumble. Future returns on stocks may well be lower than the past decade's lavish annual average of nearly 14%. Even so, we should thank our lucky stars for living at a time when we can capture nearly all the return stocks produce.

title: 'Dominion' Review: The Christian Revolution
summary: Christ's radical teachings shattered the certainties of the ancient world-and should still unsettle our own.. Two decades before the birth of Jesus of Nazareth, the Roman poet Virgil ended his epic poem of Roman origins, the "Aeneid," with an unforgettable image of violence. In the final lines of the poem, Aeneas, the founder of the Roman race, whose descendants are destined to rule over the peoples of the earth, plunges his sword into the breast of a defeated enemy in a fit of rage. A century later, John chose to end his biography of another great founder-figure with a very different scene. A huddle of poor fishermen sit in the dawn light by the shore of a lake, eating a simple meal of grilled fish. Jesus sits beside them, and three times he asks Peter if he loves him. Three times Peter says yes, and each time Jesus replies, "Feed my sheep." It is a scene of forgiveness, compassion and hope. Between the end of the "Aeneid" and the end of the fourth Gospel yawns a moral gulf as wide as a civilization.

title: 'Mudlark' Review: The Stories the River Can Tell
summary: The Thames constantly washes up centuries-old artifacts: medieval coins, Napoleonic gun flints, even Victorian love tokens.. London's Thames is a tidal river. The height between high and low water can vary from 22 feet to 15, revealing yards of muddy foreshore at its ebb. Until the early 20th century, the city's poorest-mostly old women and children-eked out a living by dredging this sludge for coal, rope and bits of iron, which they would sell for a pittance. The Victorian journalist and reformer Henry Mayhew estimated that by the mid-1880s there were around 280 "mudlarks" plashing their way through the mire, pursuing their slim pickings with "a stolid look of wretchedness," rags stiff, "bodies bent down while they peer anxiously about."

title: 'Love Unknown' Review: A Poet Out of Place
summary: Throughout her life, Elizabeth Bishop shuttled among households, countries, relationships and continents-all the while producing groundbreaking poetry of a deceptive stillness.. Elizabeth Bishop's weird, witty 1936 poem "The Gentleman of Shalott" describes a man who believes that a mirror runs down his middle, "Somewhere along the line / Of what we call the spine." The only problem is, he doesn't know which half of his body is in the mirror, and which is out-which is real, and which reflected. No matter: "The uncertainty / He says he / Finds exhilarating. He loves / That sense of constant re-adjustment." In Thomas Travisano's "Love Unknown: The Life and Worlds of Elizabeth Bishop," the poet comes off as a mirror image of her gentleman. Her experiences, too, called for uncertainty, readjustment and no shortage of exhilaration. Throughout her life, she pivoted among households, countries, relationships and continents-all the while producing groundbreaking poetry of a deceptive stillness.

title: 'The Innocents' Review: The View From Orphan Cove
summary: A brother and sister, still only children, improvise an isolated life in coastal Newfoundland with what little they gleaned from their departed parents.. 'The Innocents' is the Canadian poet and writer Michael Crummey's fifth novel. Like its predecessors, it is set against Newfoundland's uncompromising land- and seascape, in this case in the first half of the 19th century. The Best family-Sennet, Sarah, and their children Evered, Ada and baby Martha-have lived in isolation on a small cove for as long as the two older children can remember. The family's survival has depended on catching, salting and drying cod to sell to a dealer who appears twice a year on the ship Hope-in autumn to collect the fish, in spring to deliver supplies. The Bests' is the most meager of livings, but it is about to be further diminished. Martha dies, then Sarah, and shortly after, Sennet, all victims of tuberculosis. As their deaths occur in the winter when the ground is frozen, the parents must be buried at sea: Sarah by Sennet, Sennet by Evered, both wrenching and onerous tasks. The children are left to fend for themselves, Evered, "not yet twelve," and Ada, two years younger.

title: Children's Books: Maternal Devotion and Wild Lunar Honey
summary: Mother Shrew goes to the moon and back to aid her ailing child.. Popular anecdote tells of mothers who, in moments of crisis, can muster superhuman strength to save the lives of their children. In Kenneth Kraegel's exquisite picture-book fantasy "Wild Honey From the Moon" (Candlewick, 58 pages, $17.99), the illness of a little shrew fires his mother with such determination that she travels from their snug forest cottage to the surface of the moon to procure the medicine that will cure him. Illustrated with deep, rich colors, the tale of Mother Shrew's journey will lift readers ages 4-8 up and out, imaginatively speaking, while at the same time comforting them, like a cool hand on a hot forehead.

title: 'Hymns of the Republic' Review: Fighting Until the End
summary: A portrait of the last, agonized year of the Civil War, which remained very much an undecided affair, almost to its final months.. It's a favorite question among lovers of Civil War history: What was the turning point of the war? Often the answers are "Gettysburg" or "Vicksburg" or "Antietam" or some other great battle. With a hint of snarkiness, one might suggest: "Appomattox." Not just because, for all practical purposes, the Civil War ended there in April 1865 with Robert E. Lee's surrender to Ulysses S. Grant. But also because the Civil War remained very much an undecided affair right through its final year, almost to its final months. No one can afford to take the results as inevitable.

title: 'Appeasement' Review: What Were They Thinking?
summary: Britain's establishment coalesced around appeasement and bared its teeth at those who dared to oppose it.. Despite having failed spectacularly, Britain's policy of appeasing Adolf Hitler in the 1930s has never lacked for apologists. Many leading figures at the time and large numbers of historians since have sought to exculpate prime ministers Stanley Baldwin and Neville Chamberlain and their cabinets for seeking to buy off the Nazis in an attempt to avert World War II. Indeed, it is the generally accepted view in Britain today that they were right at least to have tried.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: California fights to contain fires, Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi died in a U.S. raid, Washington Nationals win the World Series and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'Agents of Influence' Review: Their Man in New York
summary: With Britain standing alone against Nazi Germany, William Stephenson was dispatched to New York to establish a covert intelligence network and seduce America into the war.. Spymasters, especially from the comfortably distant past, tend to be referred to as "legendary" when historians get around to telling their stories. Henry Hemming, writing about the wartime exploits of the Anglo-Canadian spymaster William Stephenson (1897-1989), shows admirable restraint in "Agents of Influence," his account of Stephenson's tenure as MI6's man in North America during World War II. But any study of the mastermind of a "secret plot" to bring America into the war, as the book's subtitle has it, is bound to make its hero seem somewhat legendary, especially when that same hero once saved the author's father from drowning. In Mr. Hemming's words, "my life had hung for a moment on the actions of this elliptical figure."

title: Fiction: Paris, Punks and Videotapes
summary: A sex-worker-turned-novelist is the 'rock 'n' roll Zola' of modern Paris. A sensation in France since its release in 2015, Virginie Despentes's "Vernon Subutex" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 340 pages, $16) has now come to America. Volume 1 of the trilogy is translated by the reliably outstanding Frank Wynne and sports a DayGlo-pink cover that labels the author simply "Despentes," as though she were a one-name pop icon. In France, that's not far off. Ms. Despentes took her pen name from the neighborhood of Lyon where she briefly worked as a prostitute while writing her debut, "Baise-Moi" (1993), a rape-revenge novel she later turned into a cult-hit movie. Now, with "Vernon Subutex," a sprawling, scintillating panorama of contemporary Paris, she has produced a bona fide magnum opus.

title: When Art Was Made to Be Worn
summary: An exhibition opening Nov. 10 at the Philadelphia Museum of Art highlights the moment in the 1960s when artists brought color, design and composition to wearable textiles. In the 1960s, as liberation spread and boundaries fell, art became something not just to look at but to wear. Suddenly vests sprouted disembodied eyes and mouths made of glass beads and sequins, while wool-crocheted jackets depicted fungus and frogs. "Off the Wall," a new exhibition opening Nov. 10 at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, documents an era when, in the words of wearable-art collector Julie Schafler Dale, "artists began applying principles of color, design, dimension and composition to textiles-in effect, sculpting or painting with fibers and dyes-and then animating their work, giving it volume and form by placing it on the body."

title: Five Best: Ian Sansom on War Novels
summary: The author of "September 1, 1939: A Biography of a Poem" selects works of fiction about life during wartime.. By Marguerite Duras (1985)

title: Mysteries: Hunting a Nazi Who Got Away
summary: An Auschwitz survivor glimpses a figure he's certain is his supposedly deceased Nazi tormentor.. The dependable Joseph Kanon's latest novel of historical espionage and intrigue, "The Accomplice" (Atria, 324 pages, $28), takes place in Germany and Argentina in 1962. The Nuremberg trials are 16 years in the past, but the 1960 capture of the fugitive Adolf Eichmann has provoked fresh interest in the hunting of ex-Nazis-and given new impetus to their pursuers. One such man is aging Hamburg resident Max Weill, an Auschwitz survivor who had been forced into assisting the camp doctor Otto Schramm, of whom an anguished Max says: "He took my soul."

title: This Must Be a Canadian Word
summary: Canada's Encana is moving south to the U.S. with a seemingly random new name. You wouldn't have won any prizes for guessing what Encana did or where it did it. The portmanteau of "energy" and "Canada" was, until just a few years ago, perfectly descriptive.

title: Alibaba Beats Earnings Expectations
summary: Quarterly sales rise 40%, as Chinese online retailer continues to surge despite saturated e-commerce market. BEIJING-In its first earnings report since co-founder Jack Ma stepped down as executive chairman, Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. said sales rose 40% and profit nearly tripled in its latest quarter, showing that the Chinese online retailer continues to surge despite a saturated e-commerce market.

title: Leading the Polls Now? That's No Indicator of Who Will Win the Primary
summary: Many front-runners a year before the election have failed to secure a party's nomination; Romney was an exception. Leading in the polls a year before the general election isn't a good indicator of success. Only one time in a competitive primary since 2004 has The Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll leader gone on to win their party's nomination: Mitt Romney in 2012.

title: Analysis: Jobs Report Supports Fed Case to Pause Rate Cuts
summary: The central bank is now looking for signs of 'material' weakness before cutting rates again, and the October hiring numbers provide none. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell signaled this week the central bank was done cutting interest rates unless it sees a serious slowdown in economic activity. Friday's employment report justifies that pause for now.

title: Narrow Path to Majority Emerges for Senate Democrats
summary: Republicans are playing defense in more states than Democrats are, putting GOP control of the chamber at risk. Democrats have a real, albeit narrow, path to retake control of the U.S. Senate in 2020, fueled by strong fundraising totals in some key battleground states.

title: History Suggests Small House GOP Gains in 2020
summary: Republicans are positioned to pick up seats, but a big gain appears unlikely. With one year to go until Election Day 2020, House Republicans are likely to gain seats, as dozens of Democrats will be defending districts previously won by the president their party has attacked at every turn.

title: Democrats and Republicans Promise a Defining Election
summary: Race for the White House will test appeal of president's 'America First' policies and Democrats' ability to choose a direction for the party. WASHINGTON-President Trump is seeking to brush aside impeachment proceedings and maintain economic gains to win a second term one year from now, while Democrats are wrestling over the future of their party and whether a more liberal candidate might lead them back to the White House.

title: Where a Power Lawyer Finds Her Own Counsel
summary: WilmerHale's Jamie Gorelick seeks career and leadership guidance from a journalist, a professor and colleagues; 'take care of yourself, take care of your friends'. Jamie Gorelick has spent the majority of her career giving other people advice on corporate crises and Washington, D.C. dust-ups. When she needs her own counsel, Ms. Gorelick says she seeks "empathetic" people "whose judgment I trust."

title: Despite Wildfires and Drought, California Keeps Building
summary: Farmers and developers continue to expand into remote areas, draining the state's water supply and putting its people at risk.. A few days ago, before the fires began to burn again, I took one of my seasonal treks through California. I left my house in Fresno, which sits in the middle of the state, and drove south past miles of flattened earth and imported water.

summary: As impeachment looms, auto tariffs could alienate a key constituency: GOP senators. WASHINGTON-Politics and the prospect of impeachment are emerging as potential roadblocks to threatened Trump administration tariffs on European and Asian auto imports.

summary: Insurers are likely to remain cautious about covering homes and businesses in wildfire-prone areas. A new wave of wildfires is likely to reduce the availability of home insurance in vulnerable areas of California.

summary: Colder months call for the zest of sweet-and-sour colors like lemon, tangerine and blood orange. See this season through orange-tinted glasses. Oliver Peoples sunglasses, $385, oliverpeoples.com

title: The Serenity of Studio KO
summary: As a client once memorably asked Karl Fournier and Olivier Marty, the partners behind architecture firm Studio KO: "Make me forget I'm rich." Inside the makings of their spare, earthy aesthetic. In the summer of 2017, on a dirt road cutting through scrubland around Comporta, Portugal, Karl Fournier, one half of the Paris-based architecture firm Studio KO, hopped out of a rental car to join some real estate bigwigs who were touring the site of a potential resort project. Picking his way through the native matagal, he snapped pictures of lichen-topped dunes and pine trees backcombed by the coastal wind.

title: The Professor, the President and the Pep Talk That Kicked Off a Blockchain Rally
summary: Chen Chun, who schooled China's Xi Jinping on the technology underpinning digital currencies, is in the spotlight after this week's spike in blockchain stocks. China's blockchain frenzy, which sparked rallies in an array of companies, has catapulted one academic into the limelight.

title: What Consumers Need to Know as ACA Open Enrollment Starts
summary: People who don't get coverage through an employer or other federal program have until Dec. 15 to sign up. Millions of people are expected to buy or maintain health care under the Affordable Care Act's seventh open enrollment season that starts Friday. Here's what consumers need to know.

title: Still Charming: A Classic Victorian Is Deftly Modernized
summary: To meet the needs of a modern family, a savvy designer holds on to a 1907 home's antique appeal but none of its priggishness. WHEN INTERIOR DESIGNER Robin Henry set out to update a stately Victorian home in Larchmont, N.Y., she knew its existing layout-an assortment of modest, often interconnected rooms-was mostly perfect for the modern family of six. Less ideal: The home's potential for oppressive formality.

title: St. Louis Streetcar Project Running Out of Juice
summary: Loop Trolley in St. Louis is out of money, highlighting risks of reviving old-fashioned service. St. Louis business leaders looking to boost tourism and development spent years bringing the Loop Trolley to fruition, a $52 million streetcar project that runs for 2.2 miles between a historic park and an entertainment-and-business district on the edge of the city.

summary: Insurer posts overall net profit of $648 million, reversing year-earlier loss of $1.26 billion.

summary: Festival combines concerts, culture and retail for brands. More than a hundred marketers and vendors are descending on Long Beach, Calif., this weekend for ComplexCon, a growing annual festival that combines fan service, retail sales and marketing programs.

summary: With his intensity, ruthlessness and quick wit, Eddie Jones has become one of rugby's most fascinating figures. England rugby coach Eddie Jones had been preparing to beat New Zealand for two-and-a-half years.

summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Friday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours.

summary: Move toward 'digital sovereignty' will restrict data services along national borders in a global economy, Amazon and Microsoft say. Germany and France are introducing a government-backed project to develop European cloud infrastructure in an effort to help local providers compete with U.S. technology giants, which dominate the global cloud market.

title: U.S. Withdrawal Creates Opening for Revitalized Syrian Regime
summary: Syrian forces move to reclaim areas lost in civil war, but challenges for Assad remain. Syrian President Bashar al-Assad clawed back control over much of his country with the help of Russia and Iran. Now he is poised to take back much of the rest-in large part because of the U.S.

title: China's Corruption Paradox
summary: Research suggests graft helped spur China's growth. Are Xi's anticorruption efforts undermining it?. In the 90s and early 2000s, China was very corrupt but also fast-growing. These days, the country is less corrupt by most measures but also slower growing.

summary: Former IMF chief strikes different tone than Mario Draghi in effort to heal the divided central bank. FRANKFURT-As managing director at the International Monetary Fund and a government minister in France, Christine Lagarde was renowned for her political dexterity, deftly handling recalcitrant governments, unions and business leaders.

title: Running From the Heat, Olympic Marathon Moves 500 Miles North
summary: An IOC decision to move the event to Sapporo from Tokyo prompted an angry response from the capital's governor. TOKYO-The marathon and race-walk events at next year's Summer Olympics will be held 500 miles north of the host city of Tokyo to avoid the heat of Japan's capital, the organizers and Tokyo officials said Friday.

title: GM Strike Expected to Cloud Jobs Report
summary: Watch for what is under the hood to see labor market's health. The Labor Department will issue its broadest measure of the U.S. job market on Friday, providing an update on the state of the labor market amid a broader easing of economic growth. Economists expect the jobs report will show employers added 75,000 to payrolls during the month and the unemployment rate ticked up to 3.6%, with a sizable impact from the United Auto Workers strike against General Motors expected to cloud the outlook. Here is what to watch for in the October jobs report, due out Friday at 8:30 a.m. ET.

title: Qantas Grounds Three Cracked Boeing 737 Jets
summary: Structural fault a new problem for plane maker separately working on fixes for newer MAX model. Qantas Airways Ltd. became the latest airline to ground some older Boeing Co. 737s for structural cracks, another headache for the plane maker grappling with the global grounding of the newer MAX model.

title: Video Reviews Are Hated in Soccer. That's Not the Case in Rugby.
summary: The sport has one of the most transparent video replay processes: Replays are shown on stadium screens and the conversation between the referee and the video assistant referee is broadcast. TOKYO-One player dropped an opponent on his head. Another smashed his shoulder into a rival's neck. Incidents like that have resulted in more players ejected from matches at the rugby World Cup than at the last three tournaments combined-and now, the video assistant referee has a larger role in making those calls.
